items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Llanymynech & Cae Howel river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Maesbrook.
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday evening 20/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Consequently, the risk of flooding remains for low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Thursday 24/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Aire at Allerton Ings, Barnsdale Road and Properties
items.message: River levels in the River Aire at Barnsdale Road and Allerton Ings have continued to fall since yesterday, 22/02/22. The levels within Allerton Ings are also falling steadily, however, as levels remain elevated the risk of flooding still remains. Areas most at risk are Castleford Car Centre and adjacent residential properties, with Barnsdale Road likely to remain impassable throughout today, Wednesday 22/02/2022. Although unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and put your flood plan into action. This message will be updated by 13:30, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen, however Mickletown Ings remains full. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible today, Wednesday 23/02/2022. The area most at risk is Mill Lane. Mickletown Ings is reaching capacity, therefore there is a risk that nearby properties may flood. The water levels in the Ings will remain high this morning (23/02/2022) but should begin to slowly drain over the next few days. Despite ongoing unsettled weather, we are not expecting any large rainfall amounts here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We continue to closely monitor the situation. To report flooding, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. This message will be updated by 14:05, 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

Washland levels remain high at Chapel Haddlesey as the impacts from recent rain storms move down the Lower Aire catchment. Although levels are now beginning to fall this warning remains in force as the washlands remain at levels where we may see some overtopping. Due to this increase in risk, property flooding in locations closest to the washlands is possible today, 23/02/22. Although we expect levels in the washlands to remain high for some time, we do not expect severe increases in the levels and the weather outlook is not showing significant rainfall here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Please put your flood plan into action and take care when near washlands and low-lying land, which may be flooded. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To report flooding, call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. This message will be updated by 15:00, 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.message: Heavy rain over the weekend has caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

Levels at West Holme Washlands rose throughout yesterday, 22/02/22, as a result of the persistent, heavy rainfall from Sunday, passing down the River Aire. Water levels are very high and at a level where there is a risk of property flooding to locations nearest the washlands throughout today. Though we expect levels in the washlands to remain high for some time, we do not expect significant increases in the levels. The weather outlook is not showing significant rainfall here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We expect levels to begin falling overnight, into tomorrow, 23/02/2022. We are continuing to closely monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and please put your flood plan into action. This message will be updated by 13:50, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Levels on the River Don at Fishlake remain high due to the heavy rain this weekend that resulted in the washlands steadily filling. Water has now stopped spilling into the Washlands. This warning remains in force this morning as levels in the river still indicate a higher than normal flood risk, and the Washlands still contain a significant amount of water. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours and we expect the river levels to continue falling steadily. 
We are deploying additional pumps in the area this morning, 23/2/22, which will help to reduce Washland levels more quickly. Consequently we expect the flood risk to reduce and will keep the need for this warning under review. Our field teams remain in the area monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated by 15:10, 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 8:30am on Wednesday 23 February, and over the next few hours. Water levels are now starting to drop back down to more normal levels. However this alert remains in force due to higher than normal levels being seen at Potter Heigham. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, Wednesday 23rd February, or as required.

items.message: Lake and river levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent heavy rainfall overnight. items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby remains in force. The River Ouse has peaked in York at a level of 4.58m. Low lying land around the River Ouse is at risk of flooding. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Flooding is possible, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around high tide times. We are monitoring river levels closely and expect them to stay high for several days. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated in the afternoon on Wednesday 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

The river level forecasts displayed on GOV.UK are the raw data output from the Forecasting System computer models. These have not had an expert Flood Forecaster adjustment applied. This will sometimes result in slightly different level forecasts between levels provided on GOV.UK and those shown in this message.
This message will be updated by 10am 24/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the River Ray following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 23/02/2022, in the areas around Islip and Lower Arncott.

This morning, 23/02/2022, should be mainly dry followed by scattered showers this afternoon. Further rain is then forecast overnight with the potential to be heavy at times. Levels are currently forecast to rise around Islip today before stabilising this evening. Levels have stabilised at Lower Arncott and should begin gradually falling this morning. We expect river levels will remain high and out of banks over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated this evening, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Gainsborough, Torksey, North Muskham and Colwick river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are Collingham, Sutton on Trent, North Clifton, Torksey, Lea, Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise as a result of recent rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. 

As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Wednesday, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme is operational. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Wednesday, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: A flood alert remains in force for the River Foulness and Market Weighton, this is due to high river levels in response to recent rainfall. This is likely to affect low lying land near the Market Weighton Canal, Mires Beck and River Foulness. River levels are falling slowly. There is no significant rainfall forecast in the coming days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Milford river gauge as a result of rainfall over the past 48 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue throughout Tuesday and in Wednesday, 23/02/2022. 
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into Wednesday, 23/02/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. 
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Lower Don have now peaked following the persistent, heavy, rainfall over the weekend and Monday, and continue to fall steadily. This alert remains in force as levels remain elevated at Kirk Bramwith and Norwood spillway is still operating, so the risk of flooding to low lying land and roads remains. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours but is not expected to cause further flood impacts. We expect river levels to continue to fall today, 23/02/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and washland areas, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 18:00, 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Knightsford Bridge, Bransford & Kempsey Yacht Club river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Ludlow & Tenbury river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme from Ludlow to Bransford. Locations that may be affected include Tenbury Wells and Knightwick.  
Knightsford Bridge peaked at 5.30m early Tuesday morning, 22/02/22, and Bransford peaked at 5.14m on Tuesday morning 22/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 7pm Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Bredon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning. 

Predicted peaks:- Bredon 2.8m to 2.9m on Wednesday, 23/02/22. 
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Wednesday, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but slowly falling at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels are steady but high at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
As a result of recent heavy rainfall, we expect river levels to remain high this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on Wednesday, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Low lying areas around Burstwick and Keyingham Drains and the surrounding area, including Hedon, Saltend, Burstwick, Thorgumbald and Sunk Island, are most at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. River levels rose as a result of persistent (heavy) rainfall throughout the weekend and Monday, 21/02/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. River levels have started to fall but remain above the flood risk threshold. Currently, the risk of flooding remains. Although further unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 19:15, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes. To report any property flooding, please call 0800 80 70 60.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels are high on the Lower River Derwent. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around local roads and low-lying land around Buttercrambe Weir, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue throughout today and into Wednesday, 23/02/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent.    
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday , 23/02/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Avoid contact with flood water and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Colwick and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including communities near to the River Trent, Queens Drive Park and Ride, the B6540 Tamworth Road at Sawley, Thrumpton Lane at Thrumpton, Shelford to Gunthorpe Roads, Wykes Lane at Farndon, Kelham Road and Tolney Lane at Newark, the A6097 at Gunthorpe, Fiskerton to Rolleston and Gunthorpe to East Bridgford roads Caythorpe to Hoveringham and Stoke Bardolph, and cellars of low-lying properties at Cavendish Bridge. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at 11:30 on 23/02/22 and 23:30 on 23/02/22.  Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road.  River levels are beginning to fall, but still pose a flood risk at high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling gradually at the Hints river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels in the Wharfe have peaked but we expect the lowest reaches around Cawood to remain high throughout Wednesday 23/02/22 and then fall slowly. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible. See the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and river levels. Please avoid low lying land and footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Wednesday afternoon 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse between Selby and Faxfleet remains in force due to heavy rainfall in the upper catchments and interaction with the tides. The River Ouse in York has peaked at a level of 4.58m. We expect the river to remain high throughout the morning today, 23/02/2022, and then fall slowly. Levels in Selby will remain high during the morning on Wednesday 23/02/2022. Flooding is possible, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around high tide times. We are monitoring river levels closely and expect them to stay high for several days. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated in the afternoon on Wednesday 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Further rain is forecast on Thursday morning. We expect river levels to slowly fall during Wednesday, 23/02/22. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated Wednesday evening, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are slowly rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge following last weekend’s storms. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high during Wednesday, 23/02/2022. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Wednesday 23 February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 12 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 16:00 Wednesday, 23/02/22.

River levels are slowly rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of last weekend’s storms. We expect flooding to affect the causeway at Sutton Gault. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high during Wednesday, 23/02/2022. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Wednesday 23 February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 12 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 16:00 Wednesday, 23/02/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Tuesday the 22nd of February's afternoon tide at 14:45 is expected to be 0.5m lower than the tide at 02:15 Tuesday morning 22/02/2022. The tides will remain low and gradually fall for the rest of the week, as we head towards a series of neap tides. This will reduce the risk of flooding. Strong winds will continue until the weekend, but should only generate very small amounts of windblown spray. 

Our operations staff have moved shingle at Medmerry West Beach, to try and improve the beach crest there and further reduce flood risk. We will continue to monitor the beach and weather forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

A severe flood warning is in force for the River Severn at Wribbenhall, Bewdley. Severe flooding is expected to continue. There is a danger to life. The temporary barriers at Beales Corner have exceeded their capacity on Tuesday afternoon, 22/02/22. We have withdrawn our operatives from behind the barriers. It is strongly recommended that residents evacuate from behind the defences due to the risk. You need to take action immediately to implement your emergency flood plan as severe flooding to homes & main roads is expected to continue. The level at Bewdley gauge is forecast to reach up to 5.3-5.4m Wednesday afternoon, 23/02/22. Levels are forecast to remain high for a prolonged period due to further rainfall this week. We are working closely with emergency services. If you feel your life is threatened, please dial 999 for assistance. This message will be updated by 1pm on 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at the Wharfage, Ironbridge
items.message: River levels have peaked and are starting to fall at the Buildwas river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. However, the barriers at Ironbridge remain operational and have approximately 1.6m of water against them. All EA maintenance activities have now stopped and the site has been fully evacuated behind the defences. It is strongly recommended that residents remain out of the area behind the defences due to the risk. The risk remains as the barrier system is a temporary structure, which cannot be guaranteed to perform. Buildwas gauge peaked at 6.65m early this morning, Wednesday, 23/02/22. We expect river levels to stay high for several days. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. Please follow advice from emergency services. This message will be updated by 6pm on 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
